data.name: body
data.value:
Messaging systems underpin architectures ranging from stream processing, through to event sourcing and communication between loosely-coupled microservices. To most developers the technology is not core to the business they work in, and is often disregarded as “just a pipe” for message distribution. Without understanding their capabilities and underlying design decisions, we tell ourselves myths how these systems “should” work and are frustrated in production by behaviours coming from design trade-offs.

In this session you will learn how to think about messaging as we compare and contrast the approaches taken by two similar but fundamentally different messaging platforms – Apache ActiveMQ and Apache Kafka. We will discuss how their underlying philosophies impact message distribution, reliability, scalability, and performance.

Along the way we will dip into how IOPS, latency and bandwidth affect throughput, why messaging systems do not play nicely with containers, and the unicorn of once-and-only-once delivery in distributed systems.

data.name: audience
data.value: This presentation is targeted towards developers and architects who use messaging within their systems. Participants will get an overview of how ActiveMQ and Kafka work under the covers, and how tradeoffs within these products affects application designs. No experience with messaging is assumed. Some code in slides.

data.name: title
data.value: The Myth of the Magical Messaging Fabric

Presentasjonen går igjennom erfaringer vi har fått underveis i arbeidet med å lage en løsning for å samle inn data om vegtrafikken i Norge. Systemet gir ut høykvalitets informasjon i nær sanntid og er basert på en uvanlig kombinasjon av sensorer, embedded devices, protokoller og programvare.

Gjennom dette arbeidet har vi fått erfaring i å bygge et distribuert system med en arkitektur i stadig endring. Presentasjonen vil ta for seg noen av problemene vi har hatt underveis og samtidig illustrere hvordan vi mener man bør gå fram for å lage løsninger som er mottakelige for forandringer.  

Presentasjonen vil vise at det er mange paralleller mellom det å oppnå smidighet i arkitekturer og det å oppnå god skalerbarhet.

data.name: title

data.name: body
data.value: Hvor relevant er domene-drevet design (DDD) 13 år etter Eric Evans’ velkjente blå bok kom ut for første gang? Boken og miljøet den vokste ut av var preget av hvordan større virksomheter bygget sine IT-systemer tidlig på 2000-tallet, dominert av de to store og altomfattende plattformene J2EE og .NET, så da er det naturlig å spørre seg hvordan den da kan passe inn i en verden preget av mikrotjenester, smidige metodikker og en myriade av teknologier og plattformer. På mange måter passer sentrale DDD-konsepter som “bounded context”, “core domain”, “ubiquitous language”, “distillation” og “aggregates” enda bedre inn i en slik verden enn i de store monolittene vi slet med den gang. Denne velfylte verktøykassen inneholder teknikker for hvordan vi som teknikere kan komme mye tettere på forretningen for å bedre forstå deres visjoner og behov; prinsipper for hvordan vi bedre kan designe vedlikeholdbare løsninger som er direkte koblet til de individuelle domene i bedriften; og maler for hvordan vi kan bygge autonome komponenter på en smidig måte.

data.name: audience
data.value: Foredraget krever ingen tidligere erfaring med DDD, men det er fordelaktig om du har kjennskap til de utfordringene prinsippene derfra prøver å løse, enten det er store monolitter som en ønsker å modularisere eller om du sliter med en flokk mikrotjenester som får gjeting av katter til å virke enkelt. Foredraget vil være relevant for både utviklere, arkitekter og produkteiere.

data.name: title
data.value: Mikrotjenester uten domenedrevet design er risikosport!

data.name: body
data.value:
Topic: Operations (and development) - how we set up Kafka without really understand our own requirements or how to configure Kafka to fullfill them

**

Kafka was introduced as part of a proof of concept for collecting 20 million click events a day. Other teams started using Kafka for different purposes, but our configuration was still as if it was a prototype. This lead to scaling problems, stability problems, and lost messages. We'll tell you what we did, and how we solved it. Enjoy our mistakes and learn!

**

4 years of using Kafka without really understanding the documentation, has taught us a lot. Join this session, and learn from our suboptimal solutions!

At FINN.no, Norway's biggest online classifieds site, we have been using Kafka since version 0.7 in 2012. Kafka was introduced as part of a proof of concept for collecting click events from our web front end, which had approximately 40 million page views a day. The Kafka cluster became popular, and more and more teams started using it, with our default settings. Still we did not have anyone dedicated to running and configuring Kafka - it was a best effort, and usually the latest person touching the defaults won. As the traffic, number of use cases, and topics grew, we got some scaling problems, stability problems, lost messages and a general feeling among developers that "our kafka cluster was unstable".

In the end we had to put some effort into find out what we ran, which properties we really needed, and get control over the configuration, our library code and how our clients used Kafka. Since August we haven't had a complaint, nor downtime on our Kafka cluster.

As the Germans say "Schadenfreude ist die schönste Freude".

Major points:
- Making our own client library, trying to "simplify" our developers' life
- Using a single cluster, with a single configuration, for vastly different purposes (click event streams and credit card payment)
- Single Zookeeper connection over a load balancer
- 8 Zookeeper nodes and 8 Kafka nodes - on the same 8 servers
- Running Kafka on nodes that already were nearly out of memory
- Arbitrary number of replicas
- Arbitrary number of partitions, default 128
- Auto create of topics
- Unclean leader election for topics requiring strict reliability
- No schema repository
- Layered schemas; single IDL for thrift, java artifacts for mapping
- "What is client rebalance - this has to be a bug"
- Not understanding of how auto commits work

Slides in English, presentation in Norwegian

data.name: audience
data.value: the participant will enjoy the session more if they have some basic experience of running Kafka and can relate to our mistakes.

data.name: title
data.value: 101 ways of configuring Kafka - badly  ; Hva FINN.no har lært av å kjøre Kafka

There are lots of pitfalls when creating a benchmark, yet many people just write a simple driver script, run it and use the resulting numbers without any further verification. This can result in bad decisions.

In this talk, we describe how we approached this problem when creating a macrobenchmarking framework for the popular search engine Elasticsearch. Based on this example, we share our experience, show you concrete techniques to spot accidental bottlenecks and other common problems in benchmarks in order to get accurate benchmark results.

There is not much prior knowledge required although it is beneficial to have a very basic understanding of the JVM and the available tooling (e.g. Java Flight Recorder). I intend to show some code snippets on my slides and maybe do a benchmark live demo (but no live coding).

How we believe decentralised ownership and decision making can help improve development speed and product quality over time. Where we still see complexity in FINN after we started using micro services. And how we try to use the inverse Conway manoeuvre together with DDD to extract the strategic parts of our legacy code. The talk will also address how we currently address data flows across services, and how we are moving in the direction of using events and data streams.

data.name: body
data.value: At first glance, writing concurrent programs in Java seems like a straight-forward task. But the devil is in the detail. Fortunately, these details are strictly regulated by the Java memory model which, roughly speaking, decides what values a program can observe for a field at any given time. Without respecting the memory model, a Java program might behave erratic and yield bugs that only occure on some hardware platforms. This presentation summarizes the guarantees that are given by Java's memory model and teaches how to properly use volatile and final fields or synchronized code blocks. Instead of discussing the model in terms of memory model formalisms, this presentation builds on easy-to follow Java code examples.

data.name: audience
data.value: Anybody developing concurrent programs for the JVM. Code in slides.

data.name: title
data.value: The Java memory model made easy

data.name: body
data.value:
We've been working on and incrementally deploying and upgrading a growing set of Microservices for two years now.  They support the website for a UK household-name company, and as such, through testing of every release is vital.

Over this time we've spent more and more time on our performance testing. In this session we'll describe our current approach, illustrated with lashings of war stories:

  * plan - driving all your tests from your requirements, and your greatest fears
  * setup - the importance of being as prod-like as possible, especially when you're not Netflix. Oh, and repeatability
  * perform - where request mix, load profile, duration, network flakiness and failure in its myriad forms are key
  * record - measurement, percentiles, and analysis
  * summarise - pulling out the headlines
  * investigation - when things went a bit weird and you have no idea why
  * improve - not just perf. but also visibility and diagnose-ability
  * automate - because CI/CD pipelines aren't just for functional tests

As an added bonus we've done all this with free tools so you'll get some demos and will then be able to go away and try things out for yourselves.

data.name: audience
data.value:
This session will be structured around a robust and easily-applied core method, but with most focus on the less-discussed and small-thing-but-large-impact gotchas which we've caught (and failed to catch) over the last two years.  We want to have live demos too time and infrastructure allowing.

The end result should be both educational and entertaining.

data.name: title
data.value: Distributed Architecture and Design: A Scientific Approach

data.value: Duke’s Choice Award winner libGDX is an open source cross-platform game development framework enabling its users to target Windows, Linux, Mac OS X, Android, iOS, BlackBerry, Windows Phone 10, and WebGL-enabled browsers with a single codebase. libGDX is used extensively around the world by everyone from indie developers to large studios, demonstrating the validity of Java for game development. This session provides an introduction to libGDX, including a detailed look under the covers and an exploration of the lessons learned during its development. It includes topics such as API design, platform fragmentation, cross-platform build systems, and performance considerations. It also covers aspects of OSS development such as community building and team management.

data.value: Beginners to experts should each be available to take away something from the talk. The audience will get a glimpse into Java-based game development, WORA API design principles, special considerations when doing cross-platform development, and how to manage a popular OSS project. The audience needs to be familiar with basic Java. Code in slides and some very minor live coding.

data.name: title
data.value: It’s All Fun and Games: Cross-Platform Game Development with Java and libGDX

We will be working together in groups of 2-3 people and explore gadgets, sensors, and connect with the all loving cloud. You will be controlling cool gadgets, reading values from the physical world and cooporate with groups in the room to create exciting integrations.

This is a hands-on workshop and the programming language used is Javascript. The targeted platforms are arduino and photons. The devices will be communicating through Firebase.

data.name: body
data.value: One important mitigation to prevent attacks on web applications is secure development. But one layer of security is not enough. So why not develop an application that protects and defends itself? Developers know best what needs to be protected and how to identify unusual behavior. That’s ‘Application Intrusion Detection’. In addition to the subsequent analysis of an attack, it enables the application to detect an ongoing attack itself. And to respond to an attack automatically and in real time with appropriate defense measures – before an attacker gains control of the application. This session will show you how to create more secure Java web applications by adding self-defending capabilities by utilizing ‘Application Intrusion Detection’.

data.name: audience
data.value: Every Java web developer should attend this session in order to learn how to create self defending web applications with Java. Code will be shown in slides as well as in the live demo (IDE).

data.name: body
data.value:
SQL is the winning language of Big Data. Whether you’re running a classic relational database, a column store (“NewSQL”), or a non-relational storage system (“NoSQL”), a powerful, declarative, SQL-based query language makes the difference. The SQL standard has evolved drastically in the past decades, and so have its commercial and open source implementations.

In this fast-paced talk, we’re going to look at very peculiar and interesting data problems and how we can solve them with SQL. We’ll explore common table expressions, hierarchical SQL, table-valued functions, lateral joins, row value expressions, window functions, and advanced data types, such as XML and JSON. And we’ll look at Oracle’s mysterious MODEL and MATCH_RECOGNIZE clauses, devices whose mystery is only exceeded by their power. Most importantly, however, we’re going to learn that everyone can write advanced SQL. Once you learn the basics in these tricks, you’re going to love SQL even more.

data.name: audience
data.value:

Developers, data scientists, everyone who has basic SQL skills

> How will the participants benefit from attending?
90% of the participants will learn things they've never heard before, but which they could use immediately in their projects.

Basic SQL skills are required. If participants have never worked with SQL, they might be pretty lost.

Reactive Programming is described as the next big thing of a programming paradigm.
The most common thoughts you will read about Reactive Programming is that it makes use of immutable streams and the propagation of change. At first when you hear propagation of change you might think about the observer pattern which will be delimited from what we think of Reactive Programming.
With the help of small examples, modifying arrays, we will get to know lambda expressions, filter expressions and map/reduce. Adding the concept of observables we inspect the subscription to a stream of events which turns the observer pattern the other way around and omits the usage of callbacks.
Of course there is already a manifesto, as for all fresh programming paradigms, you can sign. The manifesto states four principles of Reactive Programming at which we will take a closer look: Reactive systems are responsive, resilient, elastic and message driven.
After this overview on Reactive Programming we ask the following questions:
* Is Reactive Programming new after all?
* How do you test reactive systems?
* Who has control over a reactive system when everything is based on change?

data.name: audience
data.value: The talk is for developers and architects who have a basic understanding of functional programming and design patterns described by the Gang of Four.

data.name: title
data.value: I have a stream - Insights in Reactive Programming

Våre oppdragsgivere får ikke alltid den leveransen de forventer – i positiv forstand. Så da de ba oss om 'design til en musematte og en plakat' måtte det bli noe helt annet. Nærmere bestemt en IoT-installasjon som sekunderer et helt kundesenter i hvor gjerrige de greier å være.

I dette foredraget vil du høre om hvordan to programvareutviklere hoppet inn i sitt første kommersielle IoT-prosjekt for en kunde. Hva skjer når du bruker kjente metodikker for programvare i et hardware prosjekt? Hva gjør du når du har veldig dårlig tid til å levere et fysisk produkt? Litervis med vann og elektronikk i samme installasjon kan også by på skumle scenarier.

Vi dro inn flere teknologier i dette prosjektet, blant annet:
- Node-red
- Raspberry Pi
- ESP8266
- Highcharts
- Firebase

Vi går gjennom problemene, utfordringene, gledene og aha-opplevelsene vi støtte på, og disse er godt dokumentert med bilder og video!

If you really want to find out what goes on inside your Java application, then the debugger is your best choice. 
Are you aware of all the things modern debuggers can do?
With recent Java language advances such as lambdas, and rapid improvements by the IDE vendors it is a good time to revisit Java debugging.   
We will go through some common use cases and solve them using debugging features and strategies in IntelliJ IDEA and Eclipse:
Smart breakpoints and stepping, lambdas, monitoring classes and instances, concurrency, etc.
So come along for some debugger magic!

Redux er et rammeverk som skal ta hånd om tilstanden til applikasjonen for deg. Ved å flytte tilstanden ut av komponentene kan du lettere lage små komponenter som er lette å gjenbruke. Debuggeren til Redux lar deg også ta en tidsreise gjennom de ulike tilstandene applikasjonen har vært i - og på den måten gjøre deg lett for deg som utvikler å forstå hvordan du endte opp i en bestemt tilstand.

I denne lyntalen vil vi se på hvordan vi kan bruke Redux sammen med Angular2 og hvordan det kan være med på å gjøre dine angular-applikasjoner bedre.

data.value:
The literature and blogosphere around continuous delivery is littered with shining examples describing DevOps teams, container technologies, cloud platforms and green-field implementations. At Storebrand, our challenge was slightly different: We had an existing legacy of monolithic applications, cumbersome platforms, third-party operations teams, ITIL-heavy change processes and heavily orchestrated releases. We wanted something better, but could not throw away what we had and start again. Nor did we have any budgets or executive sponsors.

This talk will relay the story of how we moved into the world of continuous delivery one step at a time, without large rewrites or interruptions of ongoing projects. It will be a story of how ideal solutions seldom match the real-life requirements of an existing architecture, and how these can be overcome if you apply creativity, opportunism and a little bit of patience. We will also demonstrate how a loosely coupled and simplistic architecture can provide more flexibility than relying too much on a single tool or technology.

data.name: audience
data.value:
developers, architects and ops people looking to find pragmatic solutions and inspiration for adopting continuous delivery in a setting where this is difficult.

basic knowledge of infrastructure, network components and java application server deployment logistics is a benefit, but not required. The presentation will contain small parts of code in slides.

data.name: title
data.value: Continuous Delivery in a 250-year old company

data.name: body
data.value: The just-in-time compilers Java Virtual Machines make sure that the java code you wrote runs as fast as possible and that the various checks implicitly imposed by the standard do not compromise the performance. Many optimizations are speculative and profile driven. What happens to the code when the assumption becomes incorrect? This talk will cover the lifecycle of a program execution in a JVM, talk specifically about the speculative optimizations and how the JIT compiler “may get it wrong”.

data.name: audience
data.value: This talk in intended for an audience interested in understanding how their application works. As with any other performance related-talk this will be a deep dive in the JVM internals, however there is no prerequisite knowledge required to understand the content. No live coding, only code on slides.

Java 8 åpnet slusene for funksjonell programmering (FP) i Java, men verktøykassen som følger med JDKen er ganske mangelfull. Man har ingen støtte for immutable objekter og datastrukturer, som er helt essensielt innen FP og hjelper deg å fjerne en rekke typer kodefeil. I tillegg mangler for eksempel mer høynivå mekanismer for parallellisering av oppgaver.

I dette foredraget vil vi gå igjennom et utvalg av tredjepartsbiblioteker som du kan ta i bruk for å bøte på disse problemene og gjøre Java-koden din ennå mer sikker og funksjonell!

data.name: title
data.value: Hjelp, vi skal kode funksjonelt i Java!

data.name: body
data.value: We all at least heard of this language called Javascript, created in mythical 10 days with it's famous  bad and good parts. It usually feels weird and uneasy to seasoned Java/JVM developers if one has to deal with it: no compiler safety-net, no types checking, prototypal inheritance, unexpected runtime errors etc. Truth is these days Javascript is everywhere and it really pays off to be able to work on this platform. But what to do if you  feel really uncomfortable with the language itself? Meet Typescript and feel at home: compiler, types, class-based inheritance, interfaces, generics and other goodies. I'll show and try to convince you that writing client stuff as well as solid backends in Typescript can feel familiar to Java/JVM developers, be productive and fun.

data.name: audience
data.value: This talk is for developers  who prefer static types checking, compiler errors and don't feel good at dynamic languages world. I'll show that there is a way to bring more sanity to Javascript development by introducing Typescript which feels incredibly familiar to Java devs. There will be lot of code samples and some simle live coding.

data.name: title
data.value: Typescript - now you have no more excuses.

Akademia forsyner industrien med noen unge, håpefulle hvert år. Noen av dem kommer fra Westerdals Oslo ACT. Ved Westerdals innførte vi en endring for et par år siden. Fra å tidligere undervise automatisert testing krever vi nå automatiserte tester til java-koden studentene leverer. Testingen har blitt en naturlig del av vurderingsgrunnlaget.

Hvis vi gir samme oppgave til to grupper studenter, men kun den ene gruppen har krav til testedekning. Hvilke utslag gir det? Det vet vi, for vi har det nødvendige kodegrunnlaget, og vi har analysert koden via SonarQube. Du vet også snart dette, hvis du møter opp på denne lyntalen.

Lyst til å lære om maskinlæring? Interessert i hva du kan bruke det til i ditt prosjekt? 
I dette foredraget går vi gjennom grunnleggende maskinlæringsmetoder. Vi forklarer historien bak maskinlæring og teorien for de ulike metodene. Vi viser deg hvilke Java-biblioteker som kan gjøre jobben for deg, og ikke minst hva du kan bruke maskinlæring til i prosjektet ditt.
For å lage eksempler til de ulike maskinlæringsmetodene har vi tatt utgangspunkt i data om presentasjoner og foredragsholdere på tidligere års JavaZone. Vi analyserer og kategoriserer dataene for å finne nye og ukjente sammenhenger. Hvilke selskaper holder de mest avanserte presentasjonene og hvilke grupper foredragsholdere bruker flest superlativer i beskrivelsen av seg selv?
Til slutt presenter vi det optimale JavaZone-abstractet som er generert helt automatisk fra tidligere abstracts.

Beginner 
Foredraget er for alle som vil lære litt om maskinlæring. Det vil bli vist kode i presentasjonen, og du kan jaggu kjøre eksemplene selv også ved å klone vårt GitHub repo.

Estimering ER vanskelig. Selv om du sverger til  #noestimates estimerer du alltid noe uansett, og da er det jo bedre om de er litt mer riktige.

Noe av det som gjør det vanskelig er hvordan vi lurer oss selv, men med litt innsikt i hvordan hodene våre virker trenger du ikke å være så lettlurt lengre.

Kom for å få litt innsikt i ditt eget hode og hvordan du kan slutte å lure deg selv, basert på David Kahnemans prisbelønnede bok "Thinking, fast and slow".

Concurrent programming with locks is hard. Concurrent programming without using locks can be really hard. Concurrent programming with relaxed memory ordering and predictable latency semantics is said to be only for wizards. This talk focuses on a decade long quest to discover algorithms and data structures that provide very high throughput while keeping latency low and predictable. Additionally, data structures need to provide real-time telemetry on how a system is performing via non-blocking operations.

We will cover some fundamental theory of concurrency and then compare various approaches to the same problem so that we can measure the impact on latency. We'll also show how some of these algorithm implementations get more interesting given the new features in Java 8.

data.name: audience
data.value: This talk is aimed at programmers interested in advanced concurrency who want to develop algorithms with predictable response times at all levels of throughput which push our modern CPUs to the limit.

data.name: title
data.value: A quest for predictable latency with Java concurrency

data.name: body
data.value:
Exploring novel message passing data structures outside the JDK and what they offer in terms of usage patterns, performance and possibilities. We'll be looking at:
* JCTools queues: placing limitations on producer/consumer counts
* Disruptor: building a pipeline of workers on top of a pre-allocated buffer
* Aeron IPC: offheap, cross platform (Java/Native), binary message passing
* JCTools Proxy Channels: Proxy calls to other threads using custom-generated queues

Det er lite tvil om at det har skjedd mye i frontend-verden de siste 10 årene. Særlig er dette merkbart i JavaScript. Etter at vi har bevegd oss fra tynne til tykke klienter, har vi gått igjennom en transformering som har betydd høy innovasjon, stor grad av utforsking og iterativt arbeid. Det har virket for mange som det er umulig å følge med i frontend-verden og vanskelig å vite hvilke valg man skal ta.

Denne presentasjonen skal prøve å overbevise deg om at JavaScript-frykt ikke er en ting de fleste burde bekymre seg over. På samme måte som vi har smidig og utforskende arbeid på produkter, har vi det og på utvikling av økosystem og teknologier, og man kan fint få gevinsten av det uten å måtte ofre mye.

Vi vil gå igjennom historie og utviklingen av språket, utviklingen av økosystem og fellesskapet for å skjønne hvordan ting henger sammen og for å se at det ikke nødvendigvis er slik at alle må være med på all utvikling som foregår. Vi vil også se hvordan et moderne prosjekt ser ut i 2016 og hvorfor det ikke trenger å være så skremmende.

Det inneholder litt kode, men man trenger ikke å forholde seg til det.

The problem arises when we want to add a new rule, but the codebase already breaks this in thousands places from before. How do you tackle that? Especially when there is that deadline coming up. This talk proposes a way to use you version control system to help decide which lint errors should be taken into account or not and that way making it possible to gradually evolve your linter rules.

Generics are one of the most complex features of Java. They are often poorly understood and lead to confusing errors. Unfortunately, it won’t get easier. Java 10, release planned for 2018, extends Generics. It’s now time to understand generics or risk being left behind.

We start by stepping back into the halcyon days of 2004 and explain why generics were introduced in the first place back. We also explain why Java’s implementation is unique compared to similar features in other programming languages.

Then we travel to the present to explaining how to make effective use of Generics. We then explore various entertaining code examples and puzzlers of how Generics are used today.

Finally, this talk sheds light on the planned changes in Java 10 with practical code examples and related ideas from other programming languages. If you ever wanted to understand the buzz around higher kinded types or declaration site variance now is your chance!

We love our silver bullets don’t we? Constantly chasing the dream that the next big thing will solve all our past problems. It doesn’t matter if it’s a language, framework, platform or library, we’re out there chasing it. Why? Well because it’s going to solve our needs, it’s going to solve the business needs. Well supposedly it will. And how much is it going to cost? Not that much, especially if we’re not the ones paying the bills. 

It’s about time we look at the hard facts and ask those difficult questions. Are we really looking for a silver bullet?  Why are we constantly riding the technology bandwagon? Where is the churn going to take us? And at what cost?

Since July 1st 2014, all IT solutions in Norway are bound by law to follow the requirements of WCAG 2.0 including level AA. A lot of people seem to think this is so that blind people can use websites. They are not wrong, but still it is so much more. Implemented correctly, a universally designed solution will benefit all of us, and the target groups include many others, like older-, drunk- and sunbathing users. 

In this talk I will give some insights into what kind of users to think about when designing, implementing and testing IT solutions, as well as what you should think about with regards to the different user groups.

I will also present tips and methods on how to implement a solution conforming to the WCAG 2.0 AA requirements and alert you to some of the normal pitfalls. We will be looking at plenty of code examples, showing both good and bad implementations.

After listening to this talk, you will have a much better understanding of why and how to implement a universal design, and hopefully be motivated to go back to work and convince your coworkers to get on bord too!

It is very easy to get stuck in one way of doing things. This is as true of programming as it is of life. Although a programming paradigm represents a set of stylistic choices, it is much more than this: a programming paradigm also represents a way of thinking. Having only way to think about problems is too limiting. A programming paradigm represents a set of patterns of problem framing and solving and contains the ingredients of software architecture. As Émile Auguste Chartier noted, there is nothing more dangerous than an idea when you have only one idea.

Perhaps even more problematic than being stuck with a narrow view of paradigms, is being stuck with a dysfunctional view of each paradigm. For instance, many developers working in languages and frameworks that support object orientation lack a strong idea of the principles of interaction, data abstraction and granularity that support an effective view of OO, and instead surround themselves with manager objects, singletons and DTOs.

This session explores the strengths and weaknesses of different programming styles, patterns and paradigms in Java and other JVM languages.

Although the JVM takes care of cleaning up memory for you, it is still your responsibility to clean other types of resources after usage, such as file handlers, open streams, native resources etc. Usually the first cleaning method that comes to mind is the finalization mechanism. But as it often happens, the first thought is a wrong one.

In this talk I will review several methods of cleaning up unused resources: autoclosables, “wrap your lambda”, finalisers, reference queues and Cleaner classes. I will demonstrate how to use all of them and will talk about the pros and cons of each of them.

We will learn how to build highly reliable and concurrent applications, improve throughput and resource utilization without hurting readability and avoiding  complexity.

GITT tilstrekkelig mye testdata
OG la de modes godt en god periode
NÅR testdataene så må endres litt
SÅ er det ingen som tør å gjøre det

Har du hørt om Cucumber? Cucumber (https://cucumber.io/) er et testverktøy som eksekverer en spesifikasjon skrevet i et naturlig (f.eks norsk) språk, f.eks slik som over. Cucumber kan hjelpe deg i å etablere et felles språk mellom utviklere, domeneeksperter og testere, og få alle til å skrive spesifikasjoner som du som utvikler kan kjøre for å teste om systemet ditt oppfyller kravene.

Som i alle tester er det noen forutsetninger som må være på plass før testene kan kjøre. Vanligvis løser vi disse forutsetningene enten med mocking eller med testdata. Felles for begge er at det gir oss kontroll på omgivelsene i testen, men erfaringsmessig mister vi fort kontroll på både testdata og mock'er. Testdata ligger i verste fall i sql-filer eller i flate filer, mocker er jo bare "testkode" og mangler både planlegging og struktur.

I dette foredraget vil jeg foreslå en måte hvor Cucumber kan brukes ikke bare til å skrive testene dine, men også hvordan du kan få hjelp til å håndtere testdata vha. Cucumber. Og husk, testdata er ikke bare data for de automatiske testene dine, manuelle tester fortjener minst like god håndtering og kontroll av testdata.

data.value: Functional programming constructs have risen in popularity in recent years, driven by the Big Data hype.  The object-oriented paradigm is likely to remain dominant, but there is opportunity to enrich our toolboxes by picking up some instruments from the functional world. We will present a set of functional constructs applicable for asynchronous programming, error handling, and data processing. We will skip past basic and now well-known functional constructs, such as lambdas, streams, map, and reduce, and focus on techniques that are not yet part of most object-oriented programmers’ toolboxes: reactive patterns, currying, disjunctions, lenses, and more. The constructs presented will be applicable in familiar, object-oriented contexts, and not require a functional mindset.

The audience is expected to previously have seen basic functional constructs, such as lambdas. We will present working code examples in Java and Scala. We will perform little live coding, but use IntelliJ as our presentation medium and primarily show code on screen. I.e. “Code in slides”.

Every software team writes code, but some teams produce fewer bugs than others. Every software team creates new features, but some teams develop them faster than others. What do high performance teams do differently, and why are team members more focused, satisfied and relaxed? They truly work together. No 10x rockstar programmer can achieve what a well rounded, enthusiastic team can.
Sven Peters examines how the best software teams set and follow goals, integrate new members fast, ensure diversity, monitor and continually improve team health, embrace transparency, create new processes, use a playbook to guide them through every phase of development and even develop creative & flexible work spaces for multidisciplinary projects. He shares techniques including: sparring, OKRs, feature buddies, open demos, focus weeks and many more that help teams and team members to work more effectively together, and produce awesome results.

The popularity of Docker as a micro-services tool has many organizations looking to put docker into production. With years of experience working with leading edge organizations, this workshop will not only teach Docker, but will provide real-world advice on how to work with Docker for production.

This session is a workshop and as such you will need to come with a laptop with Docker 1.10+ installed. The training and labs will include:

Docker basics
Container lifecycles
Build files
Working with the Registry
Working with the docker machine
Docker compose 
This will include the dos and don'ts for a production environment.
The session will end with standing up a Mesos / Marathon environment for scaling out a docker instance. Time allowing the bonus lab is standing up Kubernetes to run Docker instances.

data.name: body
data.value:
Building mission critical data pipelines provides business with the unique advantage of providing real time analytics of all of the data flowing through the enterprise.  This gives them the ability to get hands on with the data to make more intelligent decisions.

There are several core principles for building data pipelines for mission critical applications.  The first is to to ensure the integrity of the data ingested so that no data is loss.  This ensures that accurate and high quality analytics of that data.    Another core principle is to make the data pipeline resilient to failures and able to adapt to differing volumes of data and user load.  This requires each component of the pipeline be highly available, scalable to changing demands and able to apply back-pressure during peak data loads.

In this workshop we will walk through building this type of large scale, mission critical data pipeline using Kafka, Spark Streaming and Cassandra.   The workshop will start by looking at the individual technologies that make up the data pipeline.  Then we will discuss the overall architecture of the data pipeline and how to address these core principles.  Attendees will get hands on with exercises that walk through each of the pieces of the architecture.   

In the end all attendees will have the good times flowing - with a complete end to end data pipeline!

data.name: audience
data.value: The exercises material will be available in both Scala and Java.  The attendees should be able to code in either Scala or Java at an intermediate level.

data.name: title
data.value: Let the good times flow!  Building a large scale data pipeline with, Kafka, Spark Streaming and Cassandra

Har du noen gang tenkt at feilmeldingen kunne vært bedre enn "Undefined is not a function"? Har du savnet god IDE-støtte for frontend-utvikling? Da er denne workshoppen midt i blinken for deg! Kom og se hvordan man lager en komponent-basert Angular 2 applikasjon og hvor bra utvikler-opplevelesen kan bli når du har ordentlig type-system fra TypeScript som IDEen støtter. Vi deler våre egne erfaringer fra prosjekter med TypeScript og Angular 2, viser hvor enkelt det er å komme i gang, og hvordan man unngår de vanligste fellene når kodebasen din vokser.
Veien fra Java til TypeScript er kortere enn du tror!

data.name: audience
data.value:
Alle som vil lære seg TypeScript eller Angular2. 
"Live coding"

data.name: body
data.value: Performance is not an attribute of a system, but rather an attribute of an individual user experience. Performance is all about response time, which then again is given by its code path. But how can we possibly follow the code path into the RDBMS database. The JDBC 4.1 specification together with the Oracle end-to-end metrics gives you a method to follow the code path, and to work with performance, down to a single push on a button.

data.name: audience
data.value:
Developers working with RDBMS, such as Oracle, and care about performance, should attend this presentation. The only requirement for benefiting from the presentation is that audience believe that performance is a feature, and does not happen by accident. The audience will be introduced to a method showing how to work with performance both in development, test and production.
Amount of code: "Code in slides"

data.name: title
data.value: "Performance is a feature: Instrument your code using JDBC features"

data.name: body
data.value: All hipsters know that asynchronous non-blocking code is the only way. But what does that really mean? There are many ways of writing concurrent applications. All with different tradeoffs. We wanted to find out what the best approach or approaches were, so we tried the all, so you won't have to.  We will compact our years of toil into an hour of live coding examples for you to enjoy.  Come learn from our mistakes and triumphs.  We will present you with a common problem, and several different ways to solve it.  We'll show you the benefits, the disadvantages and explanations of what is actually going on at a lower level.

data.name: audience
data.value: Anyone interested in the tradeoffs to consider when writing applications with some degree of concurrency.  There will be code in slides and live coding.

data.name: title
data.value: 5 approaches to concurrency in Java - which one is the best?

data.name: body
data.value:
A code review is basically a technical discussion which should lead to improvements in the code and/or sharing knowledge in a team. As with any conversation, it should have substance and form. 

What’s involved in a good code review? What kind of problems do we want to spot and address? Trisha Gee will talk about things a reviewer may consider when looking at changes:  what potential issues to look for; why certain patterns may be harmful; and, of course, what NOT to look at.

But when it comes to commenting on someone’s work, it may be hard to find the right words to convey a useful message without offending the authors - after all, this is something that they worked hard on. Maria Khalusova will share some observations, thoughts and practical tricks on how to give and receive feedback without turning a code review into a battlefield.

data.name: body
data.value:
Taking a machine learning system from prototype to production requires a lot more than what is typically covered in an introduction to machine learning. In this talk we show how NRK built a recommender system for on-demand video streaming, taking it from an internal prototype to a service running in production. TV viewing habits are changing, and NRK needs a recommender system to stay relevant and get better use out of NRK’s content catalog. In addition to explaining the algorithms we use, we will discuss challenges around data collection, infrastructure, model management and testing.

On to the buzzwords: The system is implemented in Scala using Apache Spark. Training runs in Google Cloud Dataproc with extensive use of Google BigQuery. Recommendations are served through a Play Framework API, deployed as Docker containers running on Mesos in both a public cloud (Microsoft Azure) and a private cloud. 

Tune in to learn how you can make your system smarter by making better use of data you already have.

data.name: audience
data.value: This talk is suitable for developers curious about machine learning and for anyone considering using machine learning in a production system (including QA people and operations people). Slides will contain some Scala code, but Scala knowledge is not necessary.

data.name: title
data.value: Machine learning at NRK: From prototype to production

data.name: body
data.value: For many years, software architecture was described as the “parts that are hard to change later”. But software architecture is the balancing of capabilities versus constraints. If build changeability one of your prime capabilities, evolutionary change becomes easier. The microservice architectural style is quite popular, but it is only one in a family of evolutionary architectures. This session defines the characteristics this family of architectural styles, along with engineering and DevOps practices necessary for implementation. I cover the principles behind evolutionary architectures, the practices needed for success, how organization and team structure affects these architectures, and specific engineer practices that facilitate evolutionary architectures. I also discuss migration strategies from common existing architectural types towards move evolutionary architectures.

data.name: body
data.value:
Schibsted is a global media and classified ads conglomerate with about
200 million unique users per month. The company is currently being
transformed away from traditional paper media and siloed sites toward
a unified global media giant. To do this, Schibsted needs to collect
data about user behaviour, and process this with machine learning.

This presentation is about we built Schibsted's infrastructure for
receiving and processing this behaviour data, which at the moment
comes to 700 million events per day, or 2 terabytes per day. The
presentation covers the architecture, design of individual services,
monitoring, and challenges in scaling and reliability. It also goes
into the interaction between legal privacy requirements and overall
architecture.

Key technologies used are Amazon Web Services, auto-scaling, Scala,
Datadog, Kinesis/S3, Docker, Mesos, Luigi, and Spark.

data.name: audience
data.value: The talk is an experience report focusing on architecture and system design, so there will be no actual code. Attendees should understand the basics of web services, threads, and databases.

data.name: body
data.value:
"Hendelsesregistrering" (Event Registration) is a prototype developed for the police in Norway, focusing on assisting crime investigations and analysis by being able to detect phenomena and patterns in crime. The aim is to give the police the information they need at the right time to make better decisions, support crime investigations, see connections between events, and identify phenomena and patterns in crime. 

The prototype is based on semantic web technologies, and adopts the Apache Jena framework for semantic web programming with Java. This presentation will go through the functional aspect of the solution, with a closer look at how the Apache Jena framework for Java supports the entire back-end stack.

data.name: audience
data.value: The talk will switch between presenting the functional aspects of the prototype as well as showing how the functionality materializes by showing code in slides and code in an IDE.

data.name: title
data.value: Disclosing patterns and phenomena in crime with semantic Java

data.name: body
data.value:
Programming a web front-end is getting increasingly more complex. Some people are boldly suggesting that JavaScript is not the ideal language to handle this complexity. A compile step is already part of the workflow for most front-end development projects, so choosing a compile to JS language shouldn't be such a big leap.

One of the many alternative languages available for the front-end that is well worth a look is Elm. Elm is a relatively young compile to JS language that has started to get quite a bit of attention in the front-end community. It is a statically typed functional language that is carefully crafted to be fun, easily approachable yet very powerful. 

In this talk you will get a quick introduction to the Elm language before diving in, to create a small sample application using Functional Reactive Programming principles. By the end of the talk you should have a better understanding of what Elm is  about and why it might be worth considering for your future web front-end projects.

data.name: audience
data.value:
This talk is for anyone doing Web front-end development that is curious about alternatives to JavaScript. A basic understanding of and curiosity towards Functional Programming will probably be helpful.

Plenty of Live coding is to be expected.

data.name: title
data.value: Elm - Awesomesauce or just yet another language for the Front-end ?

data.name: body
data.value:
By definition, intrinsics are functions which are handled specially by the compiler or the VM. The HotSpot virtual machine supports intrinsics for specific API functions in the interpreter as well as in the C1 and C2 JIT compilers. In general, intrinsics are a great possibility for optimization. But they also come at a certain cost. First of all, they are inherently platform and implementation dependent. If available, they can lead to consistency problems if they are implemented differently in the interpreter and the JIT compilers. Finally, they can change the program control (e.g. safepoint behavior) and observability (e.g. profiling, instrumentation) in subtle ways.

This talk will give you a short deep dive into the HotSpot Virtual Machine using the example of HotSpot intrinsics. It will explain how they are implemented and the implications this has for the Java VM. Finally, it will demonstrate how you can add a new intrinsic for your favourite Java method.

data.name: audience
data.value: This talk is for people interested in the details of the HotSpot Virtual Machine implementation. The audience should have a general understanding of VM technology or at least be interested in learning about it. We will do some "Live coding" during this session up to the native level.

data.name: body
data.value:
Da FINN Reise lagde sin nye plattform i 2013, var det en forutsetning at kode skulle rulles ut kontinuerlig. For å få til dette, var vi avhengige av at ny kode som traff produksjon oppførte seg som den skulle og ikke klusset det til for allerede eksisterende funksjonalitet. 

Dette er historien om hvordan Continous Integration og Continous Delivery er en naturlig del av en utviklers hverdag i FINN Reise.  Vi viser hvordan tester hjelper oss på vei, hvordan utviklernes rolle har forandret seg og tar et dykk inn i FINNs interne infrastruktur.

data.name: audience
data.value: Utviklere som vil ha kode sikkert og raskt ut i produksjon. Live koding med eksempler i Java og Groovy.

data.name: title
data.value: Hvordan FINN Reise ruller ut kode i produksjon 42 ganger om dagen

data.name: body
data.value:
The cloud is the new normal and it is time to rethink how we see machines and deployments. We have been piling layer upon layer of complexity for too long. But why should it be this way? It is time to radically simplify all this.

In this talk, we'll throw general-purpose operating systems, snowflake servers and runtime provisioning out the door. Instead you'll see how servers become disposable, how machine images are generated from scratch in seconds and how to achieve perfect environment parity from dev to prod.

This is Immutable Infrastructure. It is a profoundly important change as to how we view and treat our systems. We'll go deep. We'll look at how this affects scaling, logging, sessions, configuration, service discovery and more. We'll also look at how containers and machine images compare and why some things you took for granted may not be necessary anymore.

But beware, neither sacred cows nor kittens will be spared!

data.name: audience
data.value: This talk is for developers and architect who are deploying or looking to deploy their applications on the cloud. In this talk you'll learn about immutable infrastructure and how to solve the challenges associated your transition to get there. No code.

data.name: title
data.value: Immutable Infrastructure: Rise of the Machine Images

data.name: body
data.value: A long time ago J2EE and especially application servers were considered to be too bloated and "heavyweight". It could be quite tedious and discouraging for developers to use that technology for developing applications. But since the name change to Java EE that assumption is not true anymore. This session shows the benefits developing against a well-established standard has, what makes a framework "lightweight" and how a lightweight yet comprehensive solution for enterprise application could look like. Most of the time will be spent live-coding and comparing different approaches.

data.name: audience
data.value: The session is targeting enterprise application developers and architects. There will be a lot of live coding using and comparing different technologies.

data.name: title
data.value: Java EE - the most lightweight enterprise framework

data.name: body
data.value:
Java EE 7 holds two critical gems many developers never employ: CDI Scopes and Java EE Connectors. Do you have any code storing objects in hashmaps? You can kill that code with custom scopes. Need to interact with a system that doesn’t speak HTTP? Stop writing endless wrapping endpoints and just support that protocol natively with Java EE Connectors. We’ll explore both in detail through concrete and runnable code examples that will have you ready to code.

​We'll also explore the role of Functional programming in Java EE. With a mix of usable Java EE 7 and potential Java EE 8 features, we’ll take concepts like @Schedule annotations and Bean Validation and see how they might be fundamentally changed with Java 8 language enhancements like lambdas and method references.

data.name: audience
data.value: Beginner.  Significantly code and example driven.  All code downloadable and runnable for deeper further study.

data.name: body
data.value:
Async programming is here to stay, it has proven that it can handle the load modern applications demand. Starting with async programming can be a total mind shift, once you add scaling to the equation it can get really complex! But why does it need to be so complicated?

Reactive systems are one answer, however, today we're looking for web-scale, and for this we should consider Vert.x! Vert.x is a toolkit to create distributed reactive applications on the Java Virtual Machine. It lets you build scalable applications transparently distributed in Java, JavaScript, Ruby and Groovy. You don’t have to choose a single language, just mix them!

This session explains how the simple model promoted by Vert.x enables the construction of concurrent, scalable and efficient reactive based applications.

data.name: audience
data.value: Audience is expected to be pro efficient in Java and have basic knowledge of Maven.  There will be code in slides and some Live coding/demos.

data.name: title
data.value: Let's build a scalable async Vert.x app in < 60 min

data.name: body
data.value:
Det snakkes mye om API First og at API-er er løsningen på alle dine problemer, men har du noen gang forsøkt å benytte et API som ikke er dokumentert? 
I dette foredraget introduseres du til Swagger og hvordan det kan brukes til å presentere API-ene dine på en god måte. 
Vi tar en titt på Swagger UI, som hjelper deg med å utforske og teste API-ene dine. 
Avslutningsvis kommer du til å se hvordan vi har samlet all dokumentasjon fra alle våre mikrotjenester i én fin innpakning.

data.name: audience
data.value: For deg som har laget et superdupert API men har fått kjeft av kollegaen din fordi han ikke vet hvordan han skal bruke API-et ditt. Code in slides.

data.value: Ceylon (http://ceylon-lang.org) is a great language with awesome features and great tooling that lets you focus on getting things done. So we wrote this Android application in Ceylon: You won't believe what happened next... But you'll have to come to the talk to find out. You'll also learn 8 ways Ceylon can help you write great microservices that the government doesn't want you to know about.

data.name: audience
data.value: Anyone interested in using Ceylon to write microservices, or Android apps. Some prior knowledge of the language would be beneficial, but is not essential.

data.name: title
data.value: The most incredible Ceylon presentation you'll ever see

data.name: body
data.value:
Just getting started with building "cloud native" applications and looking for an outline for doing it in a well structured and scalable way? Or perhaps you've inherited a more mature Web-based system that needs a kick up the bum to get it organised? If you answered yes to any of the above then the 12 Factor app methodology may be for you!

The 12 Factor methodology is a set of best practices first published by one of the founders of Heroku (the popular Platform-as-a-Service platform) covering 12 different aspects of application development that apply throughout the entire life of an application, from initial development to runtime in production. By following these guidelines you will give your application a better chance at the long and happy future that it deserves.

In this talk I will introduce each of these factors and how I have interpreted them in my own experiences developing software throughout the years.

While primarily targeted at applications that will be deployed in a cloud environment, the points covered here can be applied to any software applications which run as a service (regardless of the programming language used).

data.name: audience
data.value:
This presentation is targeted towards those who are in charge of maintaining a system in need of some modernisation but are not sure where to start, as well as those who are starting a new project and are interested in learning what to consider when building the project in a flexible and maintainable manner.

The concepts are programing-language agnostic, however my own experiences are based primarily in the wonderful world of Java (surprise!). There will be some code in slides.

data.name: title
data.value: Give your apps the X(II) factor!

data.name: body
data.value:
DevOps is the new black. You need DevOps. Right now.   
What? You're not doing DevOps yet? Hurry! You're going to miss the boat!  

Sounds familiar? The same thing happened with Agile a while ago. Coined as a solution for all your problems, companies rushed to implement this 'next big thing', only to realize a few years later that they got most of it wrong by failing to understand the concepts behind it well enough in the first place.  

Don't make the same mistake again. Getting DevOps right isn't easy. It's downright hard. In this talk, I'm not going to explain how to 'do' DevOps in your organisation, since there is not just one 'right' way to do it. What I can show you however, is how NOT to do DevOps.  
This session shares 15 common misconceptions, call them anti-patterns, of DevOps. I'll talk from my own experiences in getting things wrong, explain why they are wrong and prevent you from making the same mistakes. You'll leave this session with a basic understanding of how (not) to fail at DevOps and hopefully, a smile on your face ;-)

data.name: audience
data.value: This talk is suitable for everyone with reasonable experience in software development. Since this session is more about people and process than about code, there'll be (almost) no code in this talk.

data.name: title
data.value: The DevOps disaster: 15 ways to fail at DevOps

data.name: body
data.value:
With the rise of managed services, Containers As A Service, Immutable Infrastructure etc., DevOps as we know it are dying. But it is a slow grinding death. DevOps is still being looked at as the "cool new thing" in many circles, when in fact, DevOps is just another dead end.

Join me for this lightning talk, and let's give a big fat middle finger to provisioning frameworks and server management, and succumb to our new Managed Service and Public Cloud overlords!

data.name: title
data.value: DevOps. You're fucking dead to me.

data.name: body
data.value:
Skulle du ønske at SSL-sertifikater var enkelt, gratis og at de fornyet seg selv?
Nå finnes Let's Encrypt! Let's Encrypt gir deg gratis SSL-sertifikater og fornyer disse automatisk når de er i ferd med å utløpe.

Dette er en kort introduksjon til Let's Encrypt, med en demonstrasjon av hvor enkelt det nå er å skaffe seg et SSL-sertifikat og hvordan dette fornyer seg selv.

Let's Encrypt er en åpen sertifikatutsteder, som utvikles og driftes av Internet Security Research Group (ISRG), hvis formål er å redusere de finansielle, teknologiske og kunnskapsmessige barrierene mot sikring av kommunikasjon på Internett.

data.name: audience
data.value:
Er du utvikler eller sysadmin med interesse for sikring av websider ved bruk av SSL, så er Let's Encrypt en nyhet og revolusjon som du bør kjenne til.
Av forkunnskaper er det greit å vite hva et SSL-sertifikat er og hva det brukes til. Du vil også få større utbytte av lyntalen dersom du kjenner deg igjen på en kommandolinje.

data.name: title
data.value: Let's Encrypt! Endelig er SSL-sertifikater enkelt og gratis!

data.name: body
data.value:
Many use Git at the most basic level: push, pull, and maybe branch off to isolate feature and bug fix work. But put together a few new and old effective Git commands and one can really increase productivity. Don't resort to XKCD #1597 when facing problems. Efficient, transformative personal Git workflows are not only possible, they are easy to learn. This talk will teach you exactly those.
Do you want spoilers? Think of the new "git worktree" command, think of "--autosquash", think of "subtree", and of few more interesting surprises in the Git toolchain.

data.name: audience
data.value: This session if for Git users who want to improve their productivity and knowledge of the tool.

data.name: title
data.value: Transformative Git practices: new techniques for hyper-productivity

data.name: body
data.value:
Learn about the Just In Time (JIT) optimisations made by the HotSpot JVM to dynamically optimise the performance of your code at runtime.
Learn about using the free and open-source JITWatch tool to analyse the JIT compiler decisions made by the JVM during the execution of your program.
Discover which of your methods were inlined, which allocations were eliminated through escape analysis, and identify safepoint poll points in your code.

data.name: audience
data.value:
This talk is for anyone who wants to learn more about performance tuning their Java code. It's my intention to make my talks as accessible as possible without requiring expert knowledge. I will explain the JIT subsystem and optimisations for beginners but will continue to more advanced topics which will unavoidably be quite pretty complicated!
I will present code in slides showing Java, bytecode, and assembly.

data.name: title
data.value: Understanding HotSpot JVM Performance with JITWatch

data.name: body
data.value: This talk will give a broad overview of the new features introduced in the latest Spring Data release trains. We will cover recent additions and improvements in Spring Data Commons - the module that's shared amongst the store specific ones. We'll then delve into the latest and greatest features of individual store modules, like JPA, MongoDB, Neo4j, Solr and the community ones as well.

data.name: audience
data.value: Backend developers  that are exposed to relational and non-relational persistence technologies. Live coding.

data.value:
I FINN.no har vi de siste årene konvertert en gammel monolitisk applikasjon til over 300 kjørende mikrotjenester.  Denne endringen har store utfordringer rundt feilsøking og oppetid, og krever gode overvåkningsløsninger som tidlig oppdager og varsler om feil.

Søketeamet i FINN har laget en applikasjon som kontinuerlig overvåker ca 200 metrikker og varsler både med GUI, mail, SMS når noe er feil.  Jeg vil gå gjennom tankene bak applikasjonen, vise kodeeksempler på tester vi gjør mot eksterne systemer og vise applikasjonen live.

data.name: audience
data.value:
Du er interessert i å følge koden din ut i produksjon.  Du trenger innspill og gode ideer til hva og hvordan dette kan overvåkes.
"Code in slides"

data.name: title
data.value: Øyeblikkelig oversikt over 150 ting som kan gå galt (og gjør det)

data.name: body
data.value:
After HTTP, MQTT and CoAP are perhaps the most commonly used communication protocols for connecting devices to the Internet of Things.  But what are MQTT and CoAP, and what benefits do they provide over plain old HTTP?

In this session we’ll start by looking at the limitations to using HTTP in the IoT world.  We will then introduce MQTT and CoAP, and explain why these can be compelling replacements for HTTP.  By examining the strengths and weaknesses for HTTP, MQTT and CoAP we’ll identify IoT use cases for all three.

data.name: audience
data.value:
No prior knowledge is expected or assumed.  This talk will be interesting for anyone who has tried to integrate with physical devices, whether they are an IoT Hipster or a Raspberry PI Hacker.

We'll be focusing on comparing the protocols, so there will be no code.

data.name: title
data.value: MQTT and CoAP for the Java Developer

data.name: body
data.value:
Det siste tiåret har det strømmet på med nye rammeverk i JavaScript-verdenen. jQuery, Backbone, Knockout, Ember, Aurelia, Mithril, Riot, React, Redux, puh - skal man holde seg oppdatert på alt som skjer blir det vanskelig å få noe gjort. Trenger vi virkelig alle disse? Når skal man bruke hva?

I dette foredraget presenteres den løsningen alle synes å omfavne om dagen - React og Redux. Er dette kun et blaff i vinden, det hippeste og kuleste simpelten fordi det har færrest leveår, eller har det en observerbar, objektiv kvalitetsforskjell fra resten? Hvordan kan vi vurdere det? Hvordan vil en med lang erfaring fra store javascriptkodebaser vurdere dette?

Du vil få en grundig gjennomgang av Redux-arkitekturen, og se hvordan det kan bidra til å holde kodebaser ryddige i årene som kommer uten at vi trenger å hoppe på det nyeste og fresheste.

data.name: audience
data.value:
Utviklere med interesse for frontend og store javascriptkodebaser

Code in slides

data.name: title
data.value: Neste år kommer det bare et nytt rammeverk

data.value:
Mange av oss fryser på ryggen og får piggene ut bare vi hører ordene Enterprise programvare. - Hvorfor gjør vi det?

Vi har prøvd å innføre noen kommersielle programvarekomponenter  i nettbankarkitekturen vår, som fra før er bygget på open source standardapplikasjoner og biblioteker. Innføringen har gitt oss nye erfaringer.

Kom og hør når vi forteller om utfordringene vi har hatt og hva vi har lært av dette. - Kan det være at det er noe annet enn selve programvaren som er hovedutfordringene til Enterprise programvare?

data.name: audience
data.value:
Utviklere, arkitekter og prosjektledere.

Deltakerne vil få dypere forståelse for hva en bør tenke gjennom ved innføring og bruk av Enterprise programvare.

Ingen kode.

data.name: title
data.value: - Enterprise programvare! Vart du skræmt no?

data.name: body
data.value:
Ahead-of-time (AOT) native compilation has been available for .NET for quite some time, whereas Java SE, while being older than .NET, still does not have a standard AOT compiler. Some people ask why, some people think that it could only work for certain limited types of Java applications, some people think that it is not needed.

The truth, however, is that a Java AOT compiler has been available for over a decade, as part of a compliant Java SE implementation called Excelsior JET, and it proved to be useful for many organizations around the world. In this session, I would like to dispel the common myths about Java AOT compilation and show where it has advantages over JIT compilation from the technical point of view.

data.name: audience
data.value: People that are interested in JVM internals, optimizing native code compilers and who is just curious about alternative JVM implementations may benefit from this talk.  On the other hand, the common knowledge (university level) about JVM and compilers is enough to get the most of the presentation. There is some code in slides but not so much.

data.name: body
data.value:
You are one of the most significant security threats to your company. We all know we are going to fix better passwords / encryption / firewalls / etc. one day. Getting properly hacked is one of those things that is a lot more comfortable to prevent beforehand than to gather the shattered pieces afterwards. In this talk, we will take a practical approach to good personal digital security. We will start with the easy parts before drilling through the layers of security, down to the parts that are unpredictable and dangerous. Bring your laptop and a tin foil hat.

Topics include: What it's like to get properly hacked. Using password managers. Operating system security. Browser security. Encryption, firewalls, factors, and other means of protection.

data.name: audience
data.value:
All audiences. No code. All practical application.
Perfect if you've watched the show “Mr. Robot”.

You will hopefully learn to, as they say, “get your shit together” when it comes to personal security.

data.name: body
data.value:
Whether it is Docker or the Mesos Container running with Apache Mesos means running in a container, but do you really understand cgroups and how they work? Do you understand the difference between CPU Sets and CPU Shares? Many organizations use Java for their application development, but do you understand the consequence of what impact the cgroup constraints have on the JRE? 

This talk starts with a look at the anatomy of a container including control groups (cgroups) and namespaces. Then we will take a deep understand of Java's memory management and GC characteristics and how JRE characteristics change based on core count. The session will detail specifically the difference between CPU sets and CPU shares and memory management. The session will close with a deep understanding of the consequences of running the JRE in a CPU share environment and the potential for pseudo-random behavior of running in a heterogeneous datacenter.

data.name: audience
data.value: Little code, However deep details on Cgroups and container configurations.

data.name: title
data.value: Nobody puts Java in the container

data.name: body
data.value: Etter nylige innovasjoner har interessen og forskning rundt biologisk inspirerte modeller kjent som nevrale nettverk økt kraftig. Teknikkene kalles gjerne deep learning. Gjennombruddet har gitt oss state-of-the-art modeller for tale- og bildeanalyse, med språkforståelse like bak. Gigantene Google, Facebook, Baidu mfl. har hentet inn de mest kjente forskerne innen feltet. nVidia har gått all-inn, og jobber hardt for å levere teknologien som skal drive selvkjørende biler. Google sin AlphaGo har beseiret verdens beste Go-spiller. Problemer som bare mennesker kunne løse blir stadig enklere for maskinene. Jeg skal gi bittelitt historie, vise litt om hvordan disse modellene virker, vise noen kule eksempler og fortelle litt om hva som skjer ved fronten av AI.

Kanskje vet man ingenting om dem, men lurer litt på hva som foregår. Ingen kode, men masse bilder og kule eksempler.

In his book The Rise of Superman, Steven Kotler mentioned computer programming specifically as one of the Flow triggers. Flow is the mental state of operation in which a person performing an activity is fully immersed in a feeling of energized focus, full involvement, and enjoyment in the process of the activity. In essence, flow is characterized by complete absorption in what one does.  Flow is currently studied by, among others, the Flow Genome Project, which is a interdisciplinary, global organization committed to mapping the genome of Flow by 2020 and open sourcing it to everyone. They are a collection of world-class academics, athletes and artists dedicated to taking Flow from the extreme to the mainstream. They advance Flow science and train individuals and organizations to harness Flow in their lives and work.

Flow triggering activities have been used to recover from illnesses. Arguably it is also beneficial to our health and quality of life (happiness?). A healthy and happy coder is most likely to produce a better and sustainable work, both individually as well as a team. 

In this talk I would like to examine the benefits/pitfalls of flow state in a development context. I would also like to present some practical techniques/tools that Flow Genome Project has come up and put them in the software development context.

data.name: title
data.value: Code with the Flow - Healthy coding

data.name: body
data.value: Our software systems are becoming more complex and more distributed. How do we have confidence in the resilience and redundancy of the systems we put in production? Chaos Engineering is the practice of introducing failures into your system in controlled experiments to learn how your system reacts. In this talk we will look into how to establish the steady state behavior of a system and how to start experimenting to discover if the system can handle spikes in traffic, failures and timeouts.

data.name: audience
data.value: The talk is for people in DevOps teams that are involved in how their systems perform in production. It will go into detail about how easy it is to do Chaos Engineering when using the public cloud, with some examples for AWS and Azure, but will also show how you can get started when stuck with a more traditional hosting provider. Code in slides!

data.name: title
data.value: Lord of Chaos - Becoming a Chaos Engineer

I forlengelsen av clean code bør vi også etterstrebe clean Git-historikk. For å oppnå det bruker mange av oss Git rebase, blant annet til å rydde i rotete historikk, redigere tidligere commitmeldinger eller fjerne flaue commits.

Mulighetene er endeløse når man først har lært seg å bruke rebase, men med stor makt følger stort ansvar. Hvor lurt er det egentlig å skrive om historikken i Git? Når bør du gjøre det, og når bør du la være?

Historieforfalskning forsøker vi vanligvis å unngå, men i den digitale verden må det vel være greit? Eller er det andre farer som lurer?

Sidan DevOps byrja å bli hot for ein 4-5 år sidan har bransjen sett ein bråte med DevOps-initiativ rundt omkring, men meir enn ein gong har ein starta forbetringane i feil ende. Når du høyrer på folk prata om DevOps og Kontinuerlige leveransar får du fort inntrykk av at alt har ei teknisk løysning. I så fall har du bomma ... kraftig. Gløym teknologien. Start med det mjuke.

Kom og høyr ein desillusjonert utviklar prata om kva Kodesmia i javaBin har til felles med store offentlige IT-prosjekt, korleis me automatiserte alt og samstundes gjorde alle redde for å ta på ting og kvifor eg endte opp som ein seig driftar.

De siste årene har responsivitet blitt en viktigere del av nettsideutvikling.

W3C har i løpet av den siste tiden jobbet med en ny måte å style layouten på en nettside. Det de har kommet frem til går under navnet Flexbox.

Flexbox er en layout som skal gjøre det lettere å jobbe med responsivitet og dynamiske elementer. Flere har allerede begynt å ta i bruk dette, som for eksempel React Native.

I denne lyntalen skal jeg ta for meg litt av bakgrunnen til Flexbox og hvordan man effektivt kan ta det i bruk i dag.

Dette var også noe av det de ansatte hos Facebook irriterte seg over. Så de satte seg like godt ned og laget Flow - En statisk typesjekker for Javascript.  Etter denne lyntalen trenger du aldri mer å lure på hvorfor Javascript-koden din feiler. Fra nå er Flow din venn. Flow er power!

data.name: body
data.value: Ajaxkall er et eksempel på operasjoner som er kjipe å teste. Spesielt hvis du skal reagere på responsen og kanskje gjøre nye kall, håndtere feil eller sette i gang nye operasjoner. Koden blir gjerne spagetti med mange callbacks og bruk av mocking for testing. Redux har blitt det definitive biblioteket for å håndtere oppdatering av data i React-apps, men det mangler en måte å orkestrere kompliserte og asynkrone operasjoner. Redux-saga er en mellomvare til Redux som lar deg samle komplekse flyter og sideeffekter i enkle og testbare generatorfunksjoner - helt uten bruk av mocking og callbacks. Det blir vist kodeeksempler, med full testdekning, på hvordan redux-saga løser praktiske utfordringer vi har hatt på Skatteetaten, bl.a. ajaxkall, feilhåndtering, sekvensielle og parallelle flyter, analytics, throttling og innlogging/oppstart.

Nivået er viderekommende til avansert.

Hackaton er ikke bare en metode for å få utviklere og andre til å jobbe sene kvelder, betalt kun med mat drikke, og muligheten for å vinne heder og kule gadgets. Aller viktigst er det et forum der utviklere og andre kan møtes for idemyldring og samarbeid som er verdifull og gøy for alle som er involvert.

Dagens Næringsliv har begynt å arrangere Hackaton årlig, og her vil jeg si litt om hvor nyttig og gøy dette er. Vi har opplevd originiale idéer fra uventet hold, og får implementert funksjonelle prototyper. Vi så også at utviklere, forretningsutviklere, redaksjon, designere og andre kunne samarbeide akkurat så godt som optimistene hevdet på forhånd.

Etter lyntalen håper jeg du har gode nok argumenter for å overbevise din bedrift om å arrangere dette, så du kan oppleve det selv.

"Alle" vil i skyen, og "alle" vil kjøre Devops. Det ville vi også i mitt siste prosjekt. Men et skymiljø i f.eks. Amazon AWS inneholder mange bevegelige deler. Så å sette det opp riktig er ikke nødvendigvis trivielt. Og selv når man har fått et miljø som fungerer, er det ikke helt enkelt å duplisere det, slik at testmiljøer og produksjon blir like.

Jeg går igjennom den reisen vi gjorde fra manuell konfigurasjon gjennom flere iterasjoner til dagens løsning. Jeg viser hva som skal til for å sette opp et miljø i AWS, og hvordan dette kan gjøres enklere og mer reproduserbart ved å bruke skripting og Terraform. Og i tillegg deles noen erfaringer på veien.

On a web where huge amount of data is available at all time, everywhere, there is a growing need for data consistency and data integrity. When we talk about data, we talk about all things that we may say something about. By following some simple rules about naming things you may achieve consistency and integrity by providing context to your open data. In the Semantic Web we call this data 5-starred data. 

I will explain what 5-starred data is, why it is important, and how you may make your data 5-starred. We will dip into the Linked Open Data Cloud and look at how the data are structured using W3C standards and find out what makes data in the web, rather than just on the web.

data.name: audience
data.value: This talk is for everyone who generate data, and has an interest in open data. There will be some RDF code in slides, but no knowledge of the W3C standards is needed. Although, some general knowledge of RDF is a bonus.

TDD is all good but testing is more than checking that the code does what the requirements says it should do. OK, it might happen that we forget a requirement or two. However, the majority of bugs arrives in situations that are not mentioned in the specfication. How do we discover these situations? Luck? Going back to waterfall and spending months on getting the requirements perfect before we start coding? Performing rigerous manual testing after the development is done?

Exploratory testing is a powerful approach to testing that has been used by the testing community for more than 25 years. It is especially useful when working with complex solutions, incomplete requirements and specifications, and/or time-pressure. Does the situation sounds familiar? 

In this talk we'll look at how to apply the ideas behind exploratory testing and use them to find potential error situations and write more robust code. You might not learn to win the lottery but you'll learn how to find more of the nasty bugs before you commit your code to the repository.
