What is Machine Learning as a Service? Which do I choose? How can I use it in my application?

Machine learning has long been a somewhat academic discipline, its practitioners highly specialized. But with the advent of a new class of commoditized machine learning platforms, MLaaS, Machine Learning as a Service, is now available to all developers.

MLaaS can be treated as a black box, giving developers the opportunity to dive into machine learning head first. Supply your own data, build a model using tools supported by your chosen MLaaS platform and train it using the well tested algorithms offered. When ready to dig deeper into the world of machine learning, most MLaaS platforms enables us to develop our own algorithms even better tailored to our data and models.

This talk will show you the state of the art of MLaaS, what the different vendors offer, and where you best can put it to use in your applications.

data.name: audience
data.value: No experience with machine learning needed.

data.name: title
data.value: MLaaS - Machine Learning for the rest of us

data.name: body
data.value: Love it or hate it (and a lot of people seem to hate it), Maven is a widely used tool. We can consider that Maven has been the de-facto standard build tool for Java over the last 10 years. Most experienced developers already got their share of Maven headaches. Unfortunately, new developers are going through the same hard learning process, because they don't know how to deal with Maven particularities. "Why is this jar in my build?", "I can’t see my changes!", "The jar is not included in the distribution!", "The artifact was not found!" are common problems. Learn to tame the Maven Beast and be in complete control of your build to save you countless hours of pain and frustration.

data.name: audience
data.value:
Looking into the main Java conferences around the world, you cannot find any Maven related sessions that guide you through the fundamentals. Maybe the community assumes that you should already know them, like the Java language itself. Still, recycling this knowledge could be a win-win situation for everyone. How much time developers waste with not knowing how to deal with Maven particularities?

I wrote a blog post about this: http://www.radcortez.com/maven-common-problems-and-pitfalls/ and the session is going to include most of the post information, plus additional problems and practices that can help developers to be more effective when working with Maven.

data.value:
A great search experience is a must-have for enterprise applications these days. As full-text search in databases often is limited, Elasticsearch steps in and offers powerful search services through a REST API.

Keeping your domain model and Elasticsearch in sync may seem easy first, but the devil is in the details. What about type conversions, handling of nested entities and associations or the processing of query results?

But no worries, Hibernate Search has got you covered. In this talk you will learn how to index your entity model with the help of a few annotations, let Hibernate Search take care of the database/Elasticsearch synchronization and get back managed objects from full-text queries.

Based on common use cases, you will find out how to prepare your model for indexing, synchronous and asynchronous index updates, different approaches for running searches and more. Be prepared to see code and the great combo of Hibernate Search and Elasticsearch in action.

data.name: audience
data.value: The talk is for you if you are developing Hibernate/JPA applications and would like to add full-text search functionality. You will learn how easy that task is made via Hibernate Search. You should have an average knowledge of JPA, knowledge of Elasticsearch is not required. There will be code in slides and a small amount of live coding.

data.name: title
data.value: From Hibernate to Elasticsearch in no time

data.value: You have probably heard about NoSQL but did not have time to deep dive into it nor had a chance to use it in a commercial project? NoSQL movement has been around for a while now. It's worth to have a gist of what it can do for you. This session will be a practical walk-through showing the most popular NoSQL databases, outlining their features and surprise, surprise drawbacks. Marketing hype aside, we will try to understand the differences between these databases, their programming models and learn how to properly use them in our daily work. No prior knowledge is required. Come by to learn more about Cassandra, MongoDB, Hazelcast, Redis, HBase and others!

Denne presentasjonen er en intro til testautomatisering. Hva er det? Når bør vi automatisere våre tester? Hvilke fordeler gir testautomatisering og hvilke utfordringer støter man på ved utvikling av slike tester?

Hvis du i tillegg ønsker å få noen tips i forhold til når det er hensiktsmessig å automatisere en test og hvordan man kan lykkes med testautomatisering, er dette presentasjonen for deg.

Til slutt vil jeg også vise noen eksempler på hvordan testautomatisering kan gjøres i praksis. Her vil jeg vise eksempler fra to ulike prosjekter og med verktøy som Java, Selenium WebDriver, egendefinerte DSL´er, ExtentReports, RSpec, Ruby og Capybara.

Presentasjonen har med noen få kodeeksempler.

All systems fail. In the aftermath it can be easy to point fingers and assign blame, but this can obscure important lessons and opportunities to learn. In this talk, I'll explain what a blameless post mortem is and share some experience about how our team applies them to learn from downtime and bugs. I'll also cover why it's an important activity for both developers and operators.

After this talk you will have the tools to immediately get started with blameless post mortems and a list of resources gaining a deeper understanding of how and why they work.

data.name: audience
data.value: Anyone interested in continuous learning and improvement. Anyone who believes developers should take responsibility for how their code behaves in production.

data.value: The road to nines is paved with war stories

data.name: body
data.value: I have some scary examples for you, gathered throughout many years on maintenance and on large modernization projects. Examples of code so indescribably bad that it's difficult to understand how it came to ever exist. These (anonymized) examples have been analyzed in order to determine how they came to be. Participate in this presentation so that you can avoid making the same mistakes in your next development project. ...or live with the misconception that only bad developers make bad code.

Open Source is ubiquitous. Open Source is inevitable. But why would anyone even engage in Open Source? Does making money with it even work?

Modern Open Source is not Richard Stallman's Open Source anymore. Now that even Microsoft is open sourcing .NET (and possibly: Windows?), we'll need to review our opinions about Open Source.

Large corporations have engaged in commoditising their infrastructure software via Open Source in order to increase demand for their primary offerings: PaaS, SaaS, and IaaS.

And with this new model in mind, we'll have a short look into whether it still makes sense for ISVs to engage in Open Source development, or if we should just enjoy the massive free ride.

data.name: body
data.value:
Matematikere og programmerere har lenge prøvd å finne optimale løsninger på problemer som ikke lar seg løse direkte ved å bruke algoritmer eller formler. Et eksempel på et slikt problem er The Travelling Salesman Problem. 

I noen tilfeller har man godtatt at det kan være svært vanskelig å finne den aller beste løsningen, og man har i stedet funnet strategier for å komme fram til nesten optimale løsninger. Disse kan i mange tilfeller være svært verdifulle selv om de ikke er helt helt optimale.

I naturen har insekter som maur og bier vist seg ekstremt dyktige til å finne korteste vei mellom to punkter. Dette gjør de ved å dele informasjon og dermed bygge en slags kollektiv intelligens. Basert på denne framgangsmåten har det blitt utformet en modell for kunstig intelligens som kalles "swarm intelligence". Ideen er at man lager systemer som hermer etter hvordan disse insektene kommuniserer med hverandre, for på denne måten å kunne finne tilnærmet korteste vei på en rask måte.

Vi skal se kort på hva swarm intelligence er ved hjelp av praktiske eksempler, og vi skal diskutere hvordan sverminspirerte algoritmer kan brukes på andre problemer - og hvordan dette kan bli mer relevant i fremtiden.

In this session we'll create a new programming language! We'll construct its grammar, semantics, operations and the interpreter for the language. Additionally, we'll learn about parsers and how to perform simple optimizations, both at compile time and otherwise. Most importantly we'll tackle the interoperability problem with the underlying platform, which in our case is the JVM.

This session will briefly discuss type systems, optimizations, memory management and concurrency issues that programming languages all encounter. Have you ever wanted to create a programming language of your own? After this session you will have seen all the tools you need to do so and will understand more about how are programming languages work including the challenges you’ll face.

data.name: title

Java 8 kom med et nytt og spennende streams API, som gir oss Java-utviklere helt nye muligheter for prosessering av data. I tillegg kan man enkelt velge om operasjoner på en stream skal utføres sekvensielt eller i parallell.

Det å kjøre stream-operasjoner i parallell kan ved første øyekast virke enkelt og ufarlig, men er det egentlig så lurt? Vi gjør et kort dypdykk i hvordan parallelle streams faktisk fungerer, når man bør bruke de, og ikke minst om man bør bruke de i det hele tatt.

Vi lager systemer for store bedrifter. Men som stor bedrift har man et helt økosystem av systemer. Noen systemer er kjøpt fordi man fant en god leverandør. Noen er laget fra grunnen av i for eksempel java, og noen (service busser) er der for å lage arkitekturtegningene vakrere!

Så vi kommer ikke unna at Store Bedrifter trenger Arkitektur. Men trenger vi Arkitekter? Og hvordan kan vi utvikle arkitekturen i en bedrift i riktig retning? I dette foredraget ser vi på hvordan vi som mennesker bygger organisasjoner, som bygger systemer. Det betyr at det ikke nødvendigvis blir slik som Sjefarkitekten vil !.

Kjære ansvarlige utvikler. Du bryr deg om applikasjonen din. Du bryr deg om hvor mange som bruker den, og hvordan hendelser påvirker den. Har responstiden utviklet seg i positiv eller negativ retning i det siste? Den ytelsesforbedringen du gjorde - halverte du virkelig minnebruken slik du trodde, eller økte den i stedet med 10%? Vi mener at de valgene du tar for applikasjonen bør være basert på fakta, og at disse skal være lett tilgjengelig for deg hele veien fra utvikling til produksjon. Denne informasjonen består også av mer enn disk-, minne- og cpu-bruk. Standardmetrikker er vel og bra, men det er først når du kobler disse dataene med informasjon og hendelser som er unike for akkurat din applikasjon at monitoreringsløsningen blir uunnværlig.

Vi vil i løpet av dette fordraget gi deg kunnskapen og verktøyene for å sette opp en skalerbar, robust og åpen monitoreringsløsning med bruk av InfluxDB, Grafana og Sensu, og grave dypere i de tekniske og filosofiske detaljene rundt monitorering. Vi vil også vise hvordan vi har satt opp denne løsningen for over 3000 servere, som til sammen genererer ~1 millard datapunkter per døgn.

Performance testing is traditionally a task for specialists that takes place at the very end of the software delivery life cycle. But how does this fit in with a DevOps way of working, where continuous feedback is one of the key points? It doesn't. In a world where scalability and performance are just as important as delivering new features, you need to embed performance testing in your daily development workflow: it needs to become a natural part of development. And this is where Gatling comes in: an open source load testing framework based on Scala, Akka and Netty. In this session, you will learn how to use Gatling to incorporate performance testing in development and how to provide your team with continuous feedback on your application's performance.
Subjects include an introduction to Gatling, automated recording and processing of performance tests with the Gatling Scala DSL and integration with Jenkins for automated execution, bench marking and reporting of load tests.

data.name: audience
data.value: You need a basic understanding of test automation and performance testing to make the most out of this session. The talk will be a combination of slides and live coding.

data.name: title
data.value: Continuous performance: load testing for developers with Gatling

Jenkins Pipeline is a game changing way to write automation jobs with Jenkins. Pipeline supports from simple one-step hello-world type jobs to the most complex parallel pipelines or Docker operations like creation or publication of images. Best of all, they support manual/automated intervention and also an extension mechanism to avoid the DRY effect on your build pipeline. Combining Jenkins Pipeline with Docker can seriously reduce friction in your DevOps efforts. 

But Jenkins Pipeline is not the only new thing that are in Jenkins 2.0, there is also UX improvements better out-of-the-box experience and a new website.

Come to this session to learn what’s new in Jenkins 2.0 and how you can improve your Continuous Delivery Pipeline with Jenkins Pipeline as well as see what is coming after Jenkins 2.0.

data.value: Code in slides, major benefits for Developers and DevOps guys.

Dette er et erfaringsforedrag om hvordan dette, nå et år senere, har gått. 
Hvordan fungerer java til funksjonell programmering nå? 
Hva er det beste med å komme tilbake, og hva er det verste?
Har oppholdet i Scalaland endret hvordan jeg skriver Javakode?

Ethereum er den første virkelig globale, singleton datamaskinen. En datamaskin du ikke kan skru av. Ethereum er en blockchain, men viktigere - en plattform for forandring.
Dette foredraget vil gi en introduksjon til hvordan Ethereum kom til, og gjennom noen brukstilfeller vise deg hvordan du kan skrive DApps (desentraliserte applikasjoner).
Du vil få vite hvordan Ethereum ble en moden platform, basert på styrken bak bitcoin, og få innsikt i erfaringer med å utvikle på det.
Du vil også få en mer detaljert oversikt over verktøy, rammeverk og testplatformer som eksister, slik at du kan gå videre og skrive både raske og avanserte applikasjoner selv.

I Giant Leap er vi i gang med to spennende beaconprosjekter. Det ene er et pilotprosjekt for en stor norsk matvarekjede, og i det andre bruker vi beacons til betaling.  Matvarekjeden vil bruke beacons for å gi kunder en bedre handleopplevelse. I det prosjektet er vi i ferd med å utvikle en app som skal gi kunder riktig tilbud til riktig tid. I utvikling av betalingsløsningen er vi helt nede på jernet. Bruk av beacons er nybrottsarbeid, og i kjølvannet det følger det er en rekke spennende utfordringer. I matvareprosjektet må vi ta stilling til en rekke motsetninger; vi må ta hensyn til personvern, og samtidig gi en personlig tilpasset kjøpsopplevelse. Vi vil gi god informasjon, uten å irritere kundene. 
I betalingsprosjektet er en av de største utfordringene hvordan vi utnytter IP6-protokoll maksimalt.

I dette foredraget vil vi gjerne fortelle hva vi har lært om bruk av beacons, så langt; Mobil- og Javautvikling kan vi, men beacons er litt nytt for oss ennå. Vi vil fortelle om hvilke utfordringer vi har møtt på og hvordan vi har gått frem for å løse dem, både konseptuelt og teknisk, med vår beacons - mobil - Java- stack. 
Vi har snublet litt underveis, men kom vi i mål? Kom, så skal du få høre.


Giant Leap Technologies er Norges fremste kompetansemiljø innen mobil tjenesteutvikling. http://www.giantleap.no/

We all know we have Anonymous, LulzSec, and NSA around. With this in mind, isn’t it time to think about the security of our systems? Well, of course. In this talk, we’ll show how Domain Driven Design is used to counteract security weaknesses without one thinking “security” all the time. So, if you’re interested in learning how to design secure software, then this session is for you.
Business and technical attacks are two kinds of attacks, where the latter is most famous, e g SQL Injection & XSS. But it doesn’t mean business attacks are less harmful. On the contrary, they tend to be extremely sophisticated and powerful as they often leave infrastructure intact without firing alarms. Domain Driven Security is the field that counteracts both categories by using tools and mindsets from DDD.

data.name: audience
data.value:
Primarily intended for the seasoned developer who want to write secure code, but who also has realised that the day-to-day development work does not leave room for thinking “security” all the time. You probably carry roles as system architect or lead developer, or have informal roles as goto-guy/gal.
There will be code in slides and the discussion will be about principles for how to write code.

data.name: title
data.value: Your Business is under Attack; Arm yourself with Domain Driven Security

Terraform is a tool for defining, creating and changing versioned infrastructure in a safe and efficient way. The tool lets you define infrastructure using a simple JSON-like syntax, and services from different cloud providers, both public and private, can be combined to create advanced setups.

Terraform being provider agnostic, all kinds of services ranging from low-level resources like virtual machines and disk storage, to high level services like DNS and email can be managed. 

This presentation is packed with demos, showcasing most of the features found in Terraform.

data.value: If you're interested in software defined infrastructure, IT-automation, cloud or devops, this presentation is for you. Expect lots and lots of live coding.

Hands-on introduction to React Native – Facebook's open source library for building cross-platform native mobile apps.  

You'll make a messaging client for a simple chat API. You can choose if you want to develop for Android or iOS (or both!). 

In this workshop you'll gain insight in how you can use your web development skills to create native mobile apps with React Native. You'll see how you can leverage popular JavaScript libraries like React, Redux, fetch, etc., without sacrificing the native look and feel. You'll create the layout using Flexbox, which React Native "borrows" from CSS.

Devices (phones, tablets, etc.) already consume most services/data, but they have to get those services somewhere! In this session, learn how to use proven patterns & open source software to quickly and effectively build edge services - API gateways - that marshal & streamline communication between your key services and end-users with devices in hand. This session addresses vital points such as:

* Leveraging OAuth2 for service security
* Configuration services
* Microservice registration and discovery
* Circuit breakers for graceful degradation

Additional topics discussed include logging & tracing, testing approaches, and migration patterns.

The presenter will demonstrate how to develop & manage microservices & expose them via an edge service, securely, using OSS tools employed by Netflix to keep movies streaming globally 24x7.

data.name: audience
data.value:
Participants will learn:

* how to quickly and effectively build edge services
* how to integrate edge services with existing services
* how to optimize for mobile devices
* how to leverage edge services securely

Knowledge of microservices and/or Java is helpful, but not required.

(Live coding)

data.name: title

The arrival of Java 8 has made it possible to make better APIs.
I have made a new JSON library for Java 8, which encodes the RFC
using functional programming style.

In this talk I will walk you through how I did this, using 
concepts as Algebraic Data Types (ADTs) and other useful functional
programming patterns like Isomorphisms and Functor and CoFunctors.

I will describe a way of using fold as the basic building block for 
expressing your api, and as the most powerful tool in the ADT.

Lastly I will explain how we can use these techniques to 
do decoding and encoding of JSON without using reflection in Java 8.

Developers interested in functional programming

Code demo and in slides

Hibernate is the most popular JPA provider and knowing its inner-workings can make the difference between a high-performance enterprise application and one that barely crawls.  

This presentation goes through the most common performance bottlenecks issues like exotic mappings, too much flushing, inappropriate queries, JDBC batch updates misuse, and suboptimal result set fetching.

Aside from common anti-patterns, I will also present some very useful Hibernate features like the enhanced identifier generators, locking-likelihood reduction, caching strategies and bytecode enhancements.

data.name: audience
data.value:
This presentation is relevant for any Java developer that has ever worked with JPA and Hibernate. That being said, it's best to have some prior knowledge of JPA and/or JDBC.

This presentation aims to offer a different perspective to JPA and Hibernate because it's focused on high-performance features.

No code

With Java 9, modularity comes to your doorstep (whether you ordered it or not). This isn't your average language feature: making the most out of it may involve rewiring your brain. In this session we explore the benefits of a modular codebase using Java 9 modules. Because who doesn’t like more reliable and secure applications, meanwhile killing the dreaded classpath?

After reviewing the basic concepts of modules, we'll explore modularity patterns that enhance your design and development skills. We all have existing software, so migration of codebases to a modular world is an important topic as well. Automatic modules, the 'unnamed' module and other new concepts are added to your toolbox to this end.

Want examples? We've got plenty in this practical and code-driven talk. Even if you intend to use Java 9 without modules, this talk helps you prevent common issues. You'll be ready for Java 9 before you know it.  

Both speakers are currently writing “Java 9 Modularity” for O’Reilly, expected early 2017. They have extensive experience under the belt already with the Java 9 Jigsaw early access builds.

Isomorphic (greek: "isos" = equal, "morph" = shape) JavaScript apps are applications that can run the same code on both client-side and server-side. Isomorphism describes that if you look at the same entity in two different contexts, you should get the same thing. Here the contexts are server and client. Although the term has been mostly used in mathematics until now, it's an apt term to describe a web programing pattern where the code is shared by the front-end and back-end.
Just take an MVC-based Java framework, like the new Java EE 8 MVC 1.0, integrate it with Nashorn and use the famous JavaScript templating engine React.JS (developed by Facebook) as the "V"iew layer in MVC - that's it. Now you can render templates on the server- as also on the client side - or start rendering serverside, send them to the client and finish there! Nothing is impossible - even Netflix uses it!

data.value:
You should be familiar with JavaScript and best-case you already have some React.JS experience, as I won't make a deep-dive into React.

I'll have code in my slides as also some live demos.

data.name: title
data.value: Isomorphic JavaScript apps with Nashorn, React.JS and Java EE MVC

data.value: This is a Garbage First Garbage Collector (G1 GC) readiness session. In this session, attendees will learn more about G1 pause (young and mixed) composition, G1's remembered sets and collection set and G1's concurrent marking phase. The speaker will also cover performance tuning advice for "taming" mixed collections and evacuation failures.

data.name: audience
data.value: G1 GC will be the default collector in JDK 9. Anyone that would like to get more details on the default garbage collector and wants to understand the internals as well as take home some tuning advice is welcome to attend. The slides will have lots of GC logs (using the new logging format introduced in JDK 9). The author will also include GCHisto and JFreeCharts to provide GC information to the attendees.

data.value: I denne lyntalen skal vi se på hvordan vi brukte fossefall, parallelitet og relativitet til å håndtere statiske data i vår applikasjon. I tillegg skal vi forsøke å besvare de store spørsmålene her i livet: Kan statisk data aldri endre seg? Hvor skal den statiske dataen leve?

En introduksjon til Kotlin, et Java-aktig programmeringsspråk som kjører på JVM. Kotlin har verktøyene som trengs for å skrive sikre og robuste applikasjoner med færre kodelinjer takket være en streng kompilator og pragmatisk språkdesign.

Lær det du trenger å vite for å komme i gang med Kotlin. Forstå hvilke fordeler Kotlin kan gi innenfor sikkerhet og kortfattethet. Bruk det i ditt neste prosjekt eller introduser det i en eksisterende Java-kodebase.

data.name: audience
data.value: For Java-utvikleren som er interessert i å høre om et nytt programmeringsspråk. Det vil være kodeeksempler i presentasjonen.

data.name: body
data.value:
I kategorien ikke-funksjonelle krav er sikkerhet og sporbarhet blant de viktigste, men ofte prioritert ned eller glemt i jakten på ny funksjonalitet. 

Når så sikkerhet kommer i fokus er det lett å bli paralysert av utfordringen. Det naturlige kravet er single sign-on og sporbarhet mellom alle applikasjoner og systemer. Finnes det et produkt som kan kjøpes? Vil et prosjekt kunne implementere det? 

Denne lyntalen handler om enkel teknologi og mekanismer for sikkerhet og sporbarhet mellom applikasjoner på web/intraweb og fagsystemer. JSON Web Token (jwt) brukes som underliggende standard, og det blir presentert bruk av både tredjeparts-biblioteker og skreddersydde løsninger for sikkert å spore en brukers handlinger i systemet.

data.name: audience
data.value: Dette er en presentasjon for deg som ønsker å høre om praktiske erfaringer ved bruk av jwt i et bredt systemlandskap, hvor kanal til sluttbrukere er både web og intraweb. Dette involverer hvordan single sign-on løsninger samhandler både med applikasjoner og underliggende integrasjoner.  Code level: "Code in slides"

data.name: title
data.value: Sikkerhet er ikke en one stop shop!

data.name: body
data.value:
This is your chance of being the ultimate JVM hipster and use a language “before it was cool”.

Frege is an implementation of the Haskell programming language on the JVM and was voted the most popular of the “upcoming languages” at last year's JavaOne conference. With Scala being the elephant in the functional programming room on planet JVM, can Frege be a serious contender? We'll have a look at what makes the language unique by walking through some simple code examples and then look at how Frege code can be called from Java and vice versa.

data.name: audience
data.value: This session is for anyone who are curious about other languages on the JVM or about Haskell. No previous knowledge about Haskell or functional programming is assumed. There will be code in slides which will be explained as we go.

data.name: title
data.value: Off the Deep End: Haskell on the JVM

Trenden i webutvikling går mot mer og mer avanserte klienter skrevet i JavaScript. Denne økte kompleksiteten forsøker vi å håndtere gjennom ting som ES2016,  bibliotek for funksjonell programmering, immutability, promises og en god dose disiplin. 

ClojureScript er et pragmatisk språk som hjelper deg til å lage enklere løsninger. 
Denne presentasjonen vil belyse flere grunner til at ClojureScript er verdt 
å vurdere til ditt neste prosjekt.

Kom for å se hvordan et språk kan tilby deg store fordeler og glede, hvis du bare er villig til å lære deg noe ganske annerledes enn det du er vant til.

data.name: audience
data.value:
Dette er en presentasjon for JavaScript-utviklere som er nysgjerrige på alternative verktøy for å bli mer produktive.

Det vil vises kode i presentasjonen.

data.name: title
data.value: 3 grunner til at ClojureScript gir deg superkrefter

Java's most ubiquitous library is getting an update!
And this is the time to see what's new and weigh in on its course.

This talk will...

* show you how to write tests with JUnit 5
* walk you through the changes compared to JUnit 4
* present the new architecture
* discuss compatibility with previous JUnit versions, IDEs, and other testing tools

Be careful, though:
You might end up with an urge to start using it right away.

data.name: audience
data.value:
The attendees should know JUnit and how to write tests with it. After the talk they will know why JUnit 5 was necessary, how to use and how it might improve testing on the JVM for all frameworks.

There will be code in slides.

data.name: title
data.value: JUnit 5: Next Generation Testing on the JVM

Chrome Developer Tools er tilgjengelig i alle Chrome installasjoner, men få kjenner til alle mulighetene. Å se på DOM elementer og lese console output er kjent for mange, men den kan også brukes som editor, analysere ytelse og finne minnelekasjer. Etterhvert som Javascript-applikasjoner blir mer komplekse blir avansert bruk av Chrome Developer Tools nødvendig for å skjønne hvordan applikasjonen fungerer.

I løpet av 2 timer skal vi blant annet se på hvordan åpne og endre lokale filer direkte i Chrome med sourcemaps og hvordan bruke CPU profile og flame chart for å finne kilden til ytelsesproblemer.

data.name: title
data.value: Alt du ikke visste om Chrome Developer Tools

John McCarthy innførte begrepet 'kunstig intelligens' i 1955 som en betegnelse på vitenskapen knyttet til det å lage intelligente maskiner. Fire år senere introduserte Arthur Samuel begrepet 'maskinlæring'.

Hvorfor har vi først nå begynt å snakke om disse tingene? Hva er egentlig maskinlæring og hva kan det gjøre for virksomheter? Alt dette, og mye mer, vil du få vite mer om i kontekst av dataanalyse.

data.name: audience
data.value: Alle som er interessert i og nysgjerrig på maskinlæring. "No code"

data.name: title
data.value: Maskinlæring - Hva er det og hvorfor snakker vi om det?

Interactive visualizations of large sets of data allow for completely new ways of exploring it. They are no longer static images that can be used to tell a story, but rather allow to inspect the world at a macroscopic level. Putting those visualizations into a zero-install environment like the browser makes the data accessible to anyone who has the domain knowledge but not necessarily a very technical background.

Based on a real project I will lead you through the phases of data visualisation. Preparation using pandas and pyelasticsearch. Storing and providing the data using Elasticsearch. Eventually, displaying data in the most interactive way in the browser using D3.

data.name: audience
data.value:
This is an introductory talk. I require no previous experience with any of the above techniques.
I will show some Java, Python, and JavaScript code in the slides. However, Java developers will be able to make sense of this code.

data.name: title
data.value: Worlds, not Stories: Data Exploration in the browser using Elasticsearch, Pandas, and D3

data.value: Er du klar for en smakebit på fremtidens gaming? Mesan tar deg med på en reise inn i det noe uvanlige, hvor vi skal utforske Virtual Reality og hvordan man kan lage enkle spill i full 3D ved hjelp av enkle virkemidler som papp og en mobil. Her snakker vi workshop i Android-utvikling med Java og OpenGL, Google Cardboards, matematikk og en god dose fantasi. Dette blir gøy! Vi stiller med utstyr og info, du stiller med pågangsmot og kreativitet. Ta gjerne med din egen Android-telefon om du har. Vel møtt!

Workshopen gir et innblikk i hvor enkelt man kan lage en 3D-opplevelse på mobil. Eneste forutsetningen er grunnleggende forståelse for Java. Android-kompetanse er et pluss.

data.name: body
data.value:
The LAPD makes crime report data publicly available. In this workshop you will get your hands dirty and learn to use ELK to analyze these data. ELK consist of three open source projects — Elasticsearch, Logstash, and Kibana — designed to take data from any source and search, analyze, and visualize it in real time. The philosophy behind these tools is that getting immediate, actionable insight from data matters.

During this workshop we will teach you how to:
• Get ELK up and running
• Configure Logstash to process data on LAPD crime reports
• Configure Logstash to pass the processed data to Elasticsearch
• Define a mapping template in elasticsearch to shape our data, so that you can both search and aggregate.
• Visualize the data in Kibana. Create a dashboard with a map, graphcs and tables to get insights from the data.
 
If time allows, we will show you examples on how to parse HTTP access logs and/or Java stack trace logs.

For more information, take a look at https://www.elastic.co/

data.name: audience
data.value:
What we expect from you:
• Not afraid to use a shell, though commands will be served
• Hands-on
• Eager to learn a new technology
• Not afraid to ask questions

You will need to bring your own laptop with 5GB free disk space. A virtual machine for VirtualBox will be provided to get you started.

For setup instructions, follow this link:
https://github.com/mbertani/elk-workshop/tree/javazone2016

data.name: title
data.value: Law and Order in LA - To Process and Search with ELK

Mutation testing is the true test for whether or not your source code does the right thing, and whether it's properly tested by your unit tests. But while we're on a killing spree against the mutants of our source code, let's reflect a bit on what these mutants really represent, and why we want to include the unit tests that kill them in our test suite.

What's the real point of boundary testing? Do we really need every statement in the source code? Have we tested all calculations? How do we know that we got all the access modifiers on our methods right? These are some of the questions that we would like to reflect on for a moment.

We'll start this talk with a short introduction to mutation testing, but only to set the stage. The core of this talk consists of a walk-through of Java code and unit tests, and a reflection on TDD and the quality of our unit tests. At the end of this talk you should be more suspicious about both your source code and your unit tests.

data.name: audience
data.value: Developers that want to level up from TDD and static code analysis

Our amazing web applications need high-quality UI components. So we have Angular 2 app on one hand and Material Design visual language on another. How to combine these without calling designer and spending days on struggling with CSS cross-platform issues and re-inventing client-side code for common UI scenarios? Right! Angular Material 2, set of reusable, well-tested, and accessible UI components, is going to solve this issue. It's still under active development but we can look behind the scenes and create our cross-platform, UI-rich app just in minutes. Let's go exploring and coding!

Bonus: after our app is created we'll check its Accessibility, how it's automagically added by Angular Material 2 to allow users of all abilities to navigate, understand, and use our UI successfully.

data.name: audience
data.value: Front-end developers with passion to UX. Accessibility evangelists. Responsive and adaptive UIs heroes. Live coding.

data.name: title
data.value: Angular Material 2: Reward your app with high-quality UI in minutes

What could you do if your phone could understand what it sees?

In this talk, we go though how to get an Android application to recognize what's on a picture by using OpenCV. Most of the code is not Android specific so the code will be relevant for non-mobile developers as well.

The talk will cover how to integrate with the camera, how to detect and track objects you are interested and how to classify parts of the image.

data.value:
Jolokia is a JMX-HTTP bridge which alleviates the pain of accessing JMX remotely. It is an agent based approach with support for many platforms and is integrated into popular software like Spring Boot, ActiveMQ, hawt.io or OpenShift xPaaS Middleware Images.

The next major version 2.0 brings exciting new features: JMX notification support over HTTP, new backend providers in addition to JMX so that for example Spring beans can exposed over Jolokia directly plus an internal agent modularisation which allows for custom sized Jolokia agents with only the required features. 

This talk starts with an overview over Jolokia and which problems it solves, before the Jolokia 2.0 features will be presented in an extensive live demo.

At the end you will have a good impression what is possible with JMX nowadays and how Jolokia can help you with your application monitoring and management tasks.

data.name: audience
data.value:
* DevOps who want to know an easy way to monitor Java applications via JMX
* Anybody using Jolokia 1.0 who wants to know about the forthcoming new features
* Basic to medium Java skills required (would be good if 'JMX' is not something completely new)
* Live demos

data.name: body
data.value: This presentation covers benefits and drawbacks of various popular Java EE microservices security approaches (Diffie-Hellman, RSA, HMAC) and looks at how to implement them in real-world examples. It explains why hash-based message authentication is best for microservice communication and has remained uncrackable. The presentation also shows that HMAC is fast, efficient, stateless, scalable, and DOS-resistant and can securely use any protocol and framework that supports messaging with headers, with no risk to the transport layer.

data.name: audience
data.value: Attendees should be interested in Java Security, and Java Security Alternatives.  Attendees do not need to know Java Security objects, approaches, or techniques.  Code in slides.

data.name: title
data.value: Securing your Java EE Microservice with HMAC Authentication

data.name: body
data.value: Are you tired of java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: PermGen space/Metaspace? Then this talk is for you! We'll begin with a crash course in the Java memory model in order to understand what the error message actually means. Then we'll look at different causes of the error and how to avoid them. We'll look at using Eclipse Memory Analyzer to track down memory leaks. We will glance at a few interesting mistakes from the Open Source world. Last but not least you'll learn how you can get rid of java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: PermGen space / Metaspace once and for all, using the presenters ClassLoader Leak Prevention library.

data.name: audience
data.value:
Intermediate to advanced developers. JavaEE will benefit most.

There will be code in slides (both "horror stories" and best practices), and time permitting I will do live heapdump analyzis using Eclipse Memory Analyzer.

data.name: title
data.value: Join my war on ClassLoader leaks

Ett år før planen lanserer Skatteetaten en løsning for beregning av forskuddsskatt. Løsningen er i høyeste grad ufullstendig, men har per dags dato over en million potensielle brukere.

Hvordan er dette mulig? 

I Sofus-prosjektet i Skatteetaten har man valgt å levere løsningen bit for bit. Hver dag utvides løsningen og flere brukere kan få glede av ny funksjonalitet i nye applikasjoner.  Devops og kontinuerlige produksjonssettinger har vært sentrale suksessfaktorer for å kunne levere tjenestene gradvis. Det har også vært stort fokus på mikro-tjenester, plugin-arkitektur og generell uavhengighet for å kunne levere forskuddsberegning ett år før tiden.

data.name: audience
data.value: Presentasjonen er rettet mot utviklere, arkitekter og metodister. Det vil være en del refleksjoner rundt bruk av teknologi, arkitektur og litt kode i slides.
